Headline.Para: Space dreams: Japan aerospace agency helps Singapore students' experiment proposals take flight

Snippet.Para: Japan aerospace agency helps Singapore students' experiment proposals take flight
Will a boomerang tossed in outer space return to its thrower like it does on Earth?

Headline.Para: Space dreams: Japan aerospace agency helps Singapore students' experiment proposals take flight

LeadPara.Para: Japan aerospace agency helps Singapore students' experiment proposals take flight
Will a boomerang tossed in outer space return to its thrower like it does on Earth?

TailParas.Para: Yes, said a team of students from the National University of Singapore (NUS) High School of Mathematics and Science, after accounting for the angle it is thrown.
Last month, they saw their hypothesis disproved in an experiment on board the International Space Station (ISS), conducted by Japanese astronaut Norishige Kanai.

But rather than feeling dismay, the results fuelled their interest. Secondary 2 student Paul Seow, 14, told The Straits Times: "While the results were quite different from our expectations, we believe this could be an area for future research as to how gravity affects a boomerang."

This was one of eight experiments from across Asia - three of which involved Singapore - that Dr Kanai conducted, beamed live to the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (Jaxa) in Tsukuba, a science city 1½ hours north-east of Tokyo.
The students were visiting the agency as part of the Asian Try Zero-G programme, and had the chance to take part in a mock astronaut training exercise.

Singapore Space and Technology Association (SSTA) executive director Lynette Tan told The Straits Times that the students' enthusiasm epitomises an ongoing drive and budding interest in space research among Singaporeans.
KEEP ASKING QUESTIONS

Please keep asking questions for your teachers, for your friends and for yourself. Sometimes no one can answer your question. It's okay. Because eventually you can try the experiment and find answers to your original question for yourself. Nowadays, space is getting closer and closer for everyone.
JAPANESE ASTRONAUT NORISHIGE KANAI

"Space can be a powerful technology driver and an enabler for modern business and societal progress, from urban mobility, cyber security, to climate change," she said. "People are not so averse anymore, unlike 10 years ago when they generally thought we were crazy."

The Jaxa programme is one of many global initiatives the SSTA has in store or has been invited to as a partner this year, in a sign of international recognition of Singapore's growing footprint in space.

Among these is a partnership with the European Space Agency and French national space agency CNES for the ActInSpace competition that is scouting space-related business ideas that could eventually launch start-ups. SSTA will pick a winning Singapore team in May to compete in a global tournament in Toulouse on June 26.
And then there is GoFly, sponsored by Boeing, which is calling on innovators to build the world's first personal flying device.

Another is the Mission Idea Contest, which is seeking implementable designs for satellites that address everyday needs. And in November, Singapore will host, for the second time, the annual Asia Pacific Regional Space Agency Forum, which turns 25 this year.

Ms Tan said: "The image of space has softened from the Falcon-type launches, as many realise the necessity of space-related research in our daily lives with our increasing reliance on satellite technology."
For Asian Try Zero-G, this year marked the second time Singaporean experiment proposals have been chosen, after Hillgrove Secondary's entry in 2016.
But for the first time, the students could prepare their own experiment apparatus to be sent to space.

The Jaxa initiative is open to student and youth proposals from around Asia, with selected ideas conducted on the ISS where Japan has an experiment module called Kibo, or "hope". Jaxa said a total of 169 proposals by 361 students and youth were submitted for this year.
Of these, 12 projects from seven nations were chosen, with similar experiments combined into the final eight that Dr Kanai performed.

NUS High had two proposals selected, while Naval Base Secondary and Nanyang Polytechnic had one each. While all were invited, only the NUS High students made the trip. Dr Chiam Sher-Yi, NUS High's head of research innovation and enterprise, said of the initiative: "They're used to land-based experiments, but this gives them a laboratory in space and forces them to think of different dimensions to their project."
Already, the students are keen to take their boomerang experiment forward and test new hypotheses.
Paul's teammate Fu Tianyi, 14, posited the boomerang "would return eventually but it will take quite a huge distance".

Dr Kanai said in closing remarks: "Please keep asking questions for your teachers, for your friends and for yourself. Sometimes no one can answer your question. It's okay. Because eventually you can try the experiment and find answers to your original question for yourself.
"Nowadays, space is getting closer and closer for everyone."

Article.Art: NUS High School students (in orange, from left) Fu Tianyi, 14, Kim Yongbeom, 15, Paul Seow Jian Hao, 14, Srivathsan Ram, 14, and Alexander Goo Zong Han, 14, after a mock astronaut training exercise. With them are Singapore Space and Technology Association executive director Lynette Tan, and NUS High School teachers Chiam Sher-Yi and Andre Jusuf.
